document.docTitle: Ctenodontina carrerai Sánchez & Camargo 2021, stat. rev.
document.masterDocTitle: Description of the female of Ctenodontina mochica Lamas, revalidation of Ctenodontina carrerai (Hull) stat. rev., and comments on the taxonomy and distribution of Peruvian species of Ctenodontina Enderlein (Diptera: Asilidae: Asilinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Description of the female of Ctenodontina mochica Lamas, revalidation of Ctenodontina carrerai (Hull) stat. rev., and comments on the taxonomy and distribution of Peruvian species of Ctenodontina Enderlein (Diptera: Asilidae: Asilinae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Departamento de Entomología, Museo de Historia Natural, Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos, Av. Arenales 1256, Lima- 11, Perú. sivrac 1986 @ gmail. com
Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia-INPA, COBIO-Coordenação de Pesquisas em Biodiversidade, Campus II, CEP 69067 - 375, Manaus, Amazonas, Brazil. alexssandroecs @ gmail. com

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Catostola carrerai Hull, 1958: 323
(orig. des.). Type-locality: Peru , Junín , Chanchamayo Valley. Holotype in Museu de Zoologia da Universidade de São Paulo (MZUSP);
Hull, 1962: 482
; currently lost.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
PERU : MD , [ Madre de Dios ] Tambopata , Reserva Ecológica Taricaya
22–26.ii. 2016
, 186 m, 12°31’8.36”S , 68°58’47.06”W J. Peralta & P. Sánchez ( 4♂ , 7♀
MUSM )
Addenda to the original description of the holotype based on specimens from Tambopata and dissected male terminalia.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Ctenodontina carrerai (Hull)
stat. rev.
Male. A. Lateral habitus; B. Terminalia, lateral view; C. Hind femur, lateral view; D–H. Terminalia after treatment with KOH; D. Epandrium; E. Sternite 8; F. Phallus; G. Gonocoxite and gonostylus, outer view; H. Same, inner view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments. Lamas (1973) synonymized
C. carrerai
with
C. maya
. He analyzed the holotypes of both species and concluded they were conspecific, although he observed subtle differences in the shape of the femoral swelling (shallower and almost inconspicuous in
C. carrerai
) and on the distal process of the epandrium (more pointed in
C. carrerai
), but regarded these differences as individual variation.
Ctenodontina maya
and
C. mochica
have more morphological differences in their external morphology, while
C. maya
and
C. carrerai
are much more similar. This may have led Lamas (1973) to recognize both as conspecific.

After examination of the holotype of
C. maya
and the original description and drawings of
C. carrerai
, we concluded that the synonymy proposed by Lamas (1973) is unwarranted and thus we revalidate the status of
Ctenodontina carrerai
stat. rev.

The following differences corroborate the revalidation: In
Ctenodontina carrerai
the dorsal epandrial margin does not have an indentation at mid-length ( Fig. 4B,D ) as in
C. maya
( Fig. 5D,E ); the apex of the epandrium has a short projection pointed downwards ( Fig. 4B,D ) while in
C. maya
the epandrial apex is rounded and pointed posteriorly ( Fig 5D,E ); the apex of the gonocoxite is almost sickle-shape apically ( Fig. 4G,H ), while in
C. maya
it is more enlarged, spatulate and rounded ( Fig. 5G,H ); the sternite 8 mid-posterior projection is sub-trapezoidal (expanded posteriorly) ( Fig. 4E ) while it is rounded in
C. maya
( Fig. 5F ); the posterior margin of sternite 8 has a more or less cordiform shape in
C. carrerai
( Fig. 4E ) while it is tapered and slightly rounded at the posterior corners in
C. maya
( Fig. 5F ). Lastly, the swelling on the male hind femur ( Fig. 4C ) is smaller and less conspicuous than in
C. maya
( Fig. 5A–C ). These differences corroborate the revalidation of
C. carrerai
and remove it from synonymy with
C . maya
.

Ctenodontina carrerai
is morphologically more similar to
Ctenodontina sagta Vieira, Ayala-Landa & Rafael
( Fig. 7 ) than to
C. maya
( Fig. 5 ). Both
C. carrerai
and
C. sagta
have smaller and almost inconspicuous swellings on the male hind femora ( Figs. 4C , 7A,C,D ). However, there are differences in the male terminalia. In
C. sagta
the epandrium has a conspicuous dorsal apical projection that is only slightly curved downwards, the dorsal epandrial margin has a rounded concavity on its mid-length and the anterior part of the epandrium is wider ( Fig. 7B,E ) than in
C. carrerai
( Fig. 4B,D ); the apex of the gonocoxite is more pointed in
C. sagta
( Fig. 7G,H ) than
C. carrerai
( Fig. 4G,H ).

Distribution ( Figure 8 ). Peru , departments of Junín and Madre de Dios .
Ctenodontina carrerai
is a common species at Tambopata, sympatric with
C. nairae
( Fig. 6 ), the latter recorded as
Ctenodontina sp. 1
by Fisher (1985) in his work on asilids from Tambopata Reserve, where he also recorded
C. maya
. However, material determined as
C. maya
by Fisher was not found at MUSM, nor were additional specimens of
C. maya
from this locality. Thus, it is possible that Fisher’s identification of
C. maya
may correspond to specimens of
C. carrerai
based on the synonymy proposed by Lamas. In Peru ,
C. carrerai
seems to be restricted to lower elevations than
C. maya
, as at Tambopata (~ 400 m ), although the type specimen was collected at an altitude of approximately 600 m in the Chanchamayo Valley in Junín .

Unfortunately , the type specimen of
C. carrerai
is considered lost. In two recent visits (2015 and 2017) to the Museu de Zoologia da Universidade de São Paulo ( MZUSP ), the type could not be found
.
